column1:
Urinary tract infection represents the most common bacterial infection in children less than 2 years of 
age. The incidence varies depending on age and sex.

Classifications are made according to the site, episode, severity, symptoms and complicating factors. 
For acute treatment, site and severity are most important.

The number of colony forming units (cfu) in the urine culture can vary, however, any colony count of 
one specimen indicates a high suspicion for UTI.

Due to increasing resistance numbers good antibiotic stewardship should guide the choice of 
antibiotics, taking into account local resistance patterns, old urine cultures (when available) and 
clinical parameters.
